t: Job 39
Do*pn you know when mountain goats give birth? Have*ln you watched the deer in labor?
Can*ln you count the months they are pregnant so*ln you can know the time they give birth?
They*ln crouch down to give birth to their young; they*ln deliver their newborn.
Their*ln offspring are healthy and grow up in the open field. They*ln leave and do not return.
Who*pn set the wild donkey free? Who*ln released the swift donkey from its harness?
I*ln made the desert its home, and*ln the salty wasteland its dwelling.
It*ln scoffs at the noise of the village and*ln never hears the shouts of a driver.
It*ln roams the mountains for its pastureland, searching*ln for anything green.
Would*ln the wild ox be willing to serve you? Would*ln it spend the night by your feeding trough?
Can*ln you hold the wild ox to a furrow by its harness? Will*ln it plow the valleys behind you?
Can*ln you depend on it because its strength is great? Would*ln you leave it to do your hard work?
Can*ln you trust the wild ox to harvest your grain and*ln bring it to your threshing floor?
The*pn wings of the ostrich flap joyfully, but*ln are her feathers and plumage like the stork’s?
She*ln abandons her eggs on the ground and*ln lets them be warmed in the sand.
She*ln forgets that a foot may crush them or*ln that some wild animal may trample them.
She*ln treats her young harshly, as if they were not her own, with*ln no fear that her labor may have been in vain.
For*ln God has deprived her of wisdom; he*ln has not endowed her with understanding.
When*ln she proudly spreads her wings, she*ln laughs at the horse and its rider.
Do*pn you give strength to the horse? Do*ln you adorn his neck with a mane?
Do*ln you make him leap like a locust? His*ln proud snorting fills one with terror.
He*ln paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength; he*ln charges into battle.
He*ln laughs at fear, since he is afraid of nothing; he*ln does not run from the sword.
A*ln quiver rattles at his side, along*ln with a flashing spear and a javelin.
He*ln charges ahead with trembling rage; he*ln cannot stand still at the sound of the ram’s horn.
When*ln the ram’s horn blasts, he snorts defiantly. He*ln smells the battle from a distance; he*ln hears the officers’ shouts and the battle cry.
Does*pn the hawk take flight by your understanding and*ln spread its wings to the south?
Does*ln the eagle soar at your command and*ln make its nest on high?
It*ln lives on a cliff where it spends the night; its*ln stronghold is on a rocky crag.
From*ln there it searches for prey; its*ln eyes penetrate the distance.
Its*ln brood gulps down blood, and*ln where the slain are, it is there.
